item.title: Spencer LaVere Smith
item.description:
Does your university consider legacy status (e.g., children of alumni) in admissions? If so, why? Legacy admissions give advantages to students that already have advantages. What purpose does the practice serve, and is it ethically worth it?
http://labrigger.com/blog/2023/07/30/end-legacy-considerations-in-college-admissions/

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: Did evolution create a tradeoff between walking upright and childbirth? For my new column I wrote about a new debate about an old ideas. https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/30/science/childbirth-evolution-obstetrical-dilemma.html

item.title: Kai Sandbrink
item.description: Now a bit late to Mastodon! In https://elifesciences.org/articles/81499, we show how task-driven modelling can be used to investigate the computational role of the proprioceptive system by training neural nets and comparing emergent representations side-by-side for different hypothesesThanks to @TrackingActions and @TrackingPlumes for the great supervision and @pranavm (equal contribution) and other coauthors for the great collaboration!

item.title: Total Internal Reflection
item.description: New posting! This one is a #HowTo guide on how NOT to start a research group in #academia - in other words, all the things that I wish I'd done differently or that I wish I'd been more aware of when I started back in 2015. I hope that helps anyone else out there taking their first steps in this direction! (And any comments/additions very welcome). üëá https://totalinternalreflectionblog.com/2023/07/30/shutting-up-shop-a-short-guide-on-how-not-to-start-a-research-group/

item.title: Jonathan Z Simon
item.description:
#introduction #neuroscience
Hi, I‚Äôm Jonathan Simon, new to fediscience.org, so I'm posting a new introduction. I‚Äôm an auditory neuroscientist, dad, husband, and nerd.Research-wise, I‚Äôm really interested in how the brain processes complex sounds, like attended speech in a noisy background (‚Äúthe cocktail party problem‚Äù). Typically in this case, our perception is dramatically dissociated from the physical acoustics (and not at all a reliable indicator of the sounds entering our ears).
1/3

item.title: Gaspar Jekely
item.description: Here is my #introduction. I am a biologist interested in #neuroscience and the #evolution of cells and nervous systems. My research group studies #ciliated marine larvae from a whole-organism perspective, combining behaviour, #connectomics, #imaging, #CRISPR, #modelling and other approaches. We love marine #larvae, their #neurons, #cilia, and #neuropeptides.

item.title: Chuck Darwin
item.description: The Origin of Student Debt: Regan advisor warned that Free College would create a Dangerous Educated ProletariatIt‚Äôs important to understand how Americans came to #owe the current cumulative total of *more than $1.6 trillion* for higher education.In 1970, Ronald Reagan was running for reelection as governor of California. He had first won in 1966 with confrontational rhetoric toward the University of California public college system and executed confrontational policies when in office. In May 1970, Reagan shut down all 28 UC and Cal State campuses in the midst of student protests against the Vietnam War and the U.S. bombing of Cambodia. On October 29, less than a week before the election, his education adviser #Roger A. #Freeman spoke at a press conference to defend him.Freeman‚Äôs remarks were reported the next day in the San Francisco Chronicle under the headline ‚ÄúProfessor Sees Peril in Education.‚Äù According to the Chronicle article, Freeman said, ‚ÄúWe are in #danger of producing an #educated #proletariat. ‚Ä¶ That‚Äôs dynamite! We have to be #selective on who we #allow [to go to college].‚Äù‚ÄúIf not,‚Äù Freeman continued, ‚Äúwe will have a large number of highly trained and unemployed people.‚Äù Freeman also said ‚Äî taking a highly idiosyncratic perspective on the cause of fascism ‚Äî‚Äúthat‚Äôs what happened in Germany. I saw it happen.‚Äùhttps://theintercept.com/2022/08/25/student-loans-debt-reagan/

item.title: DailyMegafauna
item.description: Today‚Äôs #megafauna is the Portuguese man o‚Äô war. Although it is often mistaken for a #jellyfish, the man-o-war is actually a #siphonophore, composed of multiple, genetically distinct, individual polyps. One of these polyps is the gas-filled float, which projects above the surface of the water and helps the man o' war float through the #oceans. This purple-blue float apparently resembles the wind-filled #sail of the 18th century warship from which the man o' war gets its name. When the man o' war encounters a threat on the ocean‚Äôs surface, this float can temporarily deflate to escape. Beneath the surface, three more polyps are attached to the float. One of these polyps digests food for the entire colony, another handles the man o' war‚Äôs sexual reproduction, and the third forms its #tentacles. These tentacles are, on average, 30 feet long, but can reach lengths up to 165 feet. They aid the man o' war in hunting by delivering a poison that paralyzes or kills smaller fish and sea creatures. The tentacles‚Äô muscles then transport the unmoving prey upwards to the digestive polyp. For humans, the tentacles‚Äô sting is incredibly painful‚Äìand it can be delivered even after the man o' war dies and washes ashore. Human deaths from man o' war stings are very rare, and usually involve allergic reactions or cardiac events. Although the stinging tentacles protect the man-o-war from many threats, it does have some natural predators. Sunfish and loggerhead turtles, which also eat jellyfish, are common predators. Several species use the man o' wars tentacles for their own defenses: the blanket octopus attaches man o' war tentacles to their own, and blue sea dragons store the man o' wars' poison-delivering nematocysts for later use. With no propulsive anatomy, man o' wars drift through the ocean with no control over their own location. Changes in wind and current patterns can drastically alter the distribution of this species from year to year. They are often found floating together in groups which can number in the thousands. Man o' wars are distributed throughout the warmer areas of Earth‚Äôs oceans‚Äìand rising temperatures are allowing them to survive in a larger range, with specimens washing ashore as far north as #Canada and #Scotland.

item.title: BBC Research & Development
item.description: Hello to our new followers, which, for the one and only time, is everyone...We'll be verifying our account very soon, but in the meantime, our top level domain should hopefully help confirm our identity, and we've also written about why we're here on Mastodon, what was involved to get here, and the other BBC accounts you can follow.Say hi, follow and give us a boost!https://www.bbc.co.uk/rd/blog/2023-07-mastodon-distributed-decentralised-fediverse-activitypub

item.title: Lili Karashchuk
item.description: Alright I defended my thesis! I'll be working at the Allen Institute for Neural Dynamics next. I will improve Anipose to make it even easier to set up 3D tracking for animals. I will also collect a large dataset of muscle dynamics & 3D kinematics on mice for building musculoskeletal models.I'm excited to hang out in this space again. Will experiment with posting progress and thoughts on new papers here more often.#neuroscience

item.title: Dr. jonny phd
item.description: Dear #neuromatchstodon - I want to call a vote on enabling elasticsearch/full text #search on the instance! I have gone through and tried to summarize how the search works, including what is indexed and what can be searched by who here: https://wiki.neuromatch.io/SearchAs far as I know no such official documentation exists, so hopefully that's helpful for other instances as well, please fact check me!The search filters are actually much more limited than I thought - full text search does not index every post that reaches the index, and it only allows a subset of accounts (mostly those that have interacted with the status in some way) to search a given post. I'd like to discuss any modifications we might like to make to the default behavior, unless other members feel like we shouldn't have it at all. Specifically I'd like to exclude posts from accounts with a 'noindex' tag in bio, among others. There are also additional search implementations that build on the base masto search we can consider. That wiki page will index conversations that happen in different places, so feel free to reply here, edit that wiki page, or join the thread we're having in the techwg-hacks channel in the discord (invite link in your announcements)
